title: 103_hr4962
content: The "Coeur d'Alene Basin Restoration Act of 1994" is cited in this section. It amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include the Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference. The Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference is established to develop a pollution prevention and restoration plan. The conference includes representatives from the EPA, Coeur d'Alene Indian tribe, and Idaho Department of Environmental Quality. The Management Conference appoints advisory committees and includes ex officio members, such as a Member of the United States House of Representatives. The Management Conference appoints advisory committees and includes ex officio members, including the Member of the United States House of Representatives representing the Coeur d'Alene Basin, who must publish a pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan within a year of enactment. The Management Conference appoints advisory committees and includes ex officio members, including the Member of the United States House of Representatives representing the Coeur d'Alene Basin, who must publish a pollution prevention, control, and restoration plan within a year of enactment. The Plan developed pursuant to this section shall clarify duties, suggest timetables, describe funding methods for programs, activities, and projects. The Plan developed must describe funding methods for programs, activities, and projects, incorporate environmental management concepts from State and Federal plans, and include a strategy for water pollution prevention in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Plan for pollution prevention and control in the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes promoting pollution prevention practices and public review and comment on the draft Plan. Upon approval of the draft plan in the State of Idaho, it will be deemed an approved management program for conservation and management purposes. Upon approval of the comprehensive conservation and management plan, it shall be implemented. The Administrator may provide grant assistance for the development of the Plan to various agencies and organizations. Grants under this subsection are for assisting development of the Plan, with a federal share not exceeding 70% of costs, and non-Federal sources providing the rest. The Administrator may provide grant assistance for the development of the Plan. The Administrator may establish terms and conditions for grants, with non-Federal sources providing the share. The definition of "Coeur d'Alene Basin" is specified, and statutory interpretation is clarified. The section authorizes appropriations to the EPA for fiscal years 1995-1999 to address environmental issues in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, including the river and lake. It clarifies that it does not affect the jurisdiction of any US or state agency, or entities related to the basin by treaty. The federal program coordination is addressed in Section 3. The Secretary of the Interior, in cooperation with the United States Geological Survey, will enhance data collection in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. This collaboration involves universities, research institutions, and state agencies in Idaho and Washington. The Secretary of the Interior, in collaboration with research institutions and state agencies in Idaho and Washington, will develop an integrated geographic information system in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. This includes converting partial recording sites to continuous monitoring stations with full gauging capabilities and establishing additional monitoring stations for data collection and groundwater mapping. The Secretary of the Interior, in collaboration with various entities, will conduct basic data collection and monitoring activities, including ground water mapping, water quality, and sediment data collection. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service will cooperate in a resource conservation program in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Wildlife Management Cooperative and the Coeur d'Alene Basin Management Conference will establish a fisheries restoration program and conduct a wildlife species and habitat assessment survey in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. The Act requires conducting a wildlife species and habitat assessment survey in the Coeur d'Alene Basin, including a survey of various species of concern. The Act mandates a survey of migratory bird populations in the Coeur d'Alene Basin to assess species of management concern. The Director of the US Fish and Wildlife Service is authorized to carry out activities related to improving fishery resources and investigating species status. The Act authorizes the Department of the Interior to appropriate funds for improving fishery resources, conducting investigations on fishery resources, and updating surveys in the Coeur d'Alene Basin for fiscal years 1995-1999. SEC. 4. RESTORATION PLAN. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Bureau of Land Management, will develop a restoration plan for public lands in the Coeur d'Alene Basin to reduce human and environmental risks. The Secretary of the Interior will develop a plan to reduce risks in the Coeur d'Alene Basin by creating a computerized inventory of mining sites, cleaning up contaminated areas, and restoring damaged natural resources. The plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes cleanup of mining contaminated sites, restoration of damaged natural resources, stream and river restoration plans, monitoring of restored areas for effectiveness. The plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes cleanup of mining contaminated sites, restoration of damaged natural resources, stream and river restoration plans, monitoring of restored areas for effectiveness, and developing a land management plan to reduce human health and environmental risks. Additionally, an integrated computerized geographical information system of cultural and ecological resources is being cooperatively developed and maintained. The plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes cleanup of mining contaminated sites, restoration of natural resources, and developing a computerized geographical information system for long-term management. Working with various wildlife agencies, wildlife and fishery habitat management plans will be developed for the Basin. Monitoring of wildlife management areas will also be provided. The plan for the Coeur d'Alene Basin includes cleanup of mining contaminated sites, restoration of natural resources, and developing a computerized geographical information system for long-term management. Additionally, there will be cooperative wildlife management areas, monitoring of wildlife management areas for effectiveness, and an integrated public recreation management plan developed with various agencies and public interests. The Bureau of Land Management has the authority to collect data on mining waste to support the cleanup and restoration efforts in the Coeur d'Alene Basin. This includes developing a public recreation management plan and providing information on public use and health risks in the area. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to conduct activities related to data collection, inventory of mining waste source areas, contaminated lands, data management, restoration activities, monitoring, accepting or acquiring mining contaminated lands for restoration, design, engineering, construction, and maintenance of restoration projects and management facilities. The Bureau of Land Management is authorized to conduct activities related to restoration projects, mine waste repositories, lake and river information programs, long-term land management plans, and maintenance of restored public lands. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these activities. Authorization of appropriations is provided to the Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management for fiscal years 1995-2002 to support restoration projects and long-term maintenance of public lands. SEC. 5. EXEMPTION FROM CERCLA LIABILITY. The EPA and DOI are exempt from liability under CERCLA for actions taken under this Act.
